It's not just the

And actually, why this buyer is
buying this house by $1 million?

Because, of course, we have
the household has two kids, and then they need three rooms.

They need three rooms. They cannot live in

And then the

So this household wants

That's a hypothetical example. And then this is

million for this accessibility

to subway stops. And then there's such

So the [INAUDIBLE] want

There's a thousands of

last component called residual. It's a residual. It's like a trash can. It's all the things you cannot

see this is hedonic model.

Hedonic model is decomposition. And you decompose a very complex
thing, which is a house--

it's a complex commodity-- into many pieces, a bundle of
pieces that you are using money

to buy. Now I just randomly

So how to estimate? That's the hedonic model. So that's the following. 1 million on the
left-hand side--

that's the total price, total
price, total willingness to pay. Then decompose to now four
components plus a trashcan.

These four components
for each components, there is a unit
price times quantity.

When we buy apples you have unit

So basically, for three rooms--

numbers This is a model. This alpha is the unit price.
